docs.lead_paragraph: ''I'm Mike,'' said one of the visitors, introducing himself to the 11th-grade health class at North Shore High School. ''I was born with holes in my nose and my forehead. I've had 35 surgeries.'' In a way, the students had already met Mike and gotten to know the five disfigured faces awaiting them in the classroom: Two days earlier, the class had watched a videotape made by their visitors and other members of Inner Faces, a support group for people with craniofacial disorders, in which they perform a theater piece, looking in the mirror and describing their feelings about how they see themselves and how they wish others would see them.

headline.main: Class Notes; At a Long Island high school, students accept the challenge of seeing differences and looking beyond them.

docs.abstract: Members of Inner Faces, support group for people with craniofacial disorders, visit 11th-grade health class at North Shore High School in Glen Head, LI. to educate students on how they deal with their affliction; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-18 China's President Wades Into American Culture Emulating his predecessor, Deng Xiaoping, President Jiang Zemin donned a gift hat in America. He was given a three-cornered colonial-style hat and wore it enthusiastically on a brief visit to Williamsburg, where he met an actor dressed as Thomas Jefferson, whom the Chinese leader frequently quotes. Deng got his ten-gallon hat at an outing to a rodeo in Texas in 1979. A18
